channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia Targets Kyiv Overnight in 9th Attack This Month
item.description: Explosions rocked the capital as air defenses intercepted the missiles. At least one person was killed in Odesa.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Another Casualty in Ukraine: Teenage Years
item.description: In a battered Ukrainian city, the war has stolen the normal experiences of teenage life. The youths mostly use humor to deal with the ferocity of the fighting around them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Denys, left, and Mykyta walking past a shell-damaged apartment building as their friends follow them in Sloviansk.

item.title: Ukraine and China Will Dominate G7 Summit, but a New Threat Lurks: A.I.
item.description: The leaders are expected to hold their first talks on a common regulatory approach to generative artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden departing Joint Base Andrews in Maryland on Wednesday for his trip to Hiroshima, Japan, for the Group of 7 summit.

item.title: As the U.S. Attends the G7, China Hosts a Summit of Its Own
item.description: Xi Jinping of China is meeting with leaders of five countries in Central Asia, a region crucial to his geopolitical ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong
item.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping at a signing ceremony ahead of the China-Central Asia Summit in Xi’an, China, on Wednesday.

item.title: Cyclone Aid Stalled in Myanmar: ‘I Just Hope We Get Help Before We Die.’
item.description: Aid groups in the war-torn country say they are having trouble gaining access to areas affected by the storm without approval from the junta.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Sai Aung Main/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: One of the places hardest hit by Cyclone Mocha was the area around Sittwe, Myanmar, where many Rohingya camps are located.

item.title: A Centuries-Old Mystery: Did This Elusive Viking City Exist?
item.description: Was a “medieval New York” called Jomsborg a literary fantasy or a historical reality? New archaeological discoveries may provide a clue.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A recreated “Slavs and Viking” settlement, with medieval craft demonstrations, re-enactments and guided tours in Wolin, Poland.

item.title: Singapore Hangs Man in Second Drug-Related Execution in Three Weeks
item.description: The man had been sentenced to death for possessing less than 3.5 pounds of cannabis, a punishment that human rights groups condemned as grossly excessive.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Singapore has long taken a harsh stance toward drug offenses.

item.title: Ukraine’s Allies Wrangle Over Sending F-16 Fighter Jets
item.description: The United States is resisting a European push for the powerful fighters. But will it relent, as it did before with tanks, rocket launchers and air defense missiles?
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Remko De Waal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Dutch F-16 jet fighter landing at Volkel air base in the Netherlands. Britain and the Netherlands are leading a European push to send the jets to Ukraine.

item.title: French Resistance Fighter Goes Public About Execution of German P.O.W.s
item.description: Forty-seven soldiers were shot dead and secretly buried shortly after D-Day, a veteran says. The story was hidden for decades.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Edmond Réveil, a former French Resistance fighter, said he had witnessed but did not participate in the mass execution of German soldiers during World War II.

item.title: Ecuador’s President Dissolves Congress Amid Impeachment Trial
item.description: President Guillermo Lasso disbanded the National Assembly as the opposition-led body was trying to oust him on embezzlement charges.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Guillermo Lasso of Ecuador during a visit to the White House in December.

item.title: He Lost Turkey’s Presidential Election, but Could Swing the Runoff
item.description: Seen by some as spoiler but by others as a kingmaker, Sinan Ogan, the far-right candidate who came in third in the vote, says he is being courted by the two finalists: the sitting president and his challenger.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: Sinan Ogan, center, is surrounded by supporters in Ankara this month.

item.title: Trounced, Conservatives Feel Voters’ Wrath in English Heartlands
item.description: Defections in the once solidly Conservative southern “blue wall” drove large losses in recent municipal elections.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Olivia Harris for The New York Times
item.media:description: George Blundell, 22-year-old newly elected member of Windsor and Maidenhead Council, collecting litter with his girlfriend, in Maidenhead, England, on Saturday.

item.title: ‘Catastrophic’ Floods in Italy Leave 8 Dead and Thousands Homeless
item.description: Intense downpours caused rivers to overflow in the northern region of Emilia-Romagna, swamping numerous cities in a catastrophe that experts described as “unprecedented.”
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Helping residents to leave their apartments in Cesena, Italy, on Tuesday after the Savio River burst its banks.

item.title: Harry and Meghan Say They Were Chased by Paparazzi in New York
item.description: The initial description of the episode in Midtown Manhattan recalled the chase that killed Harry’s mother, but the fuller picture was more complicated.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius, Mark Landler, Hurubie Meko and Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, said through a spokesperson that they had been involved in a car chase in New York.

item.title: What Is the F-16 Fighter Jet and Why Does Ukraine Want It?
item.description: The versatile and lightweight American warplane is seen by many of Ukraine’s allies as an important deterrent against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Remko de Waal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Britain and the Netherlands are pushing for F-16 fighter jets for Ukraine.

item.title: Prescription Drug Shortages
item.description: Many Americans can’t get the medications they need.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Rising global temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Among the risks from rising temperatures are intensified droughts and wildfires.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: The G7
item.description: Also, hot years ahead as global temperatures rise.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: U.S. President Joe Biden departs Joint Base Andrews, Md. enroute to Elmendorf Air Force Base, Anchorage, Alaska before continuing to his final destination, Hiroshima, Japan where he will participate in a G7 Summit working session on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Renew a Deal to Allow Ukraine to Ship Grain
item.description: Russia last year blocked exports of Ukrainian grain across the Black Sea, a vital part of the global food supply, but they resumed last summer under a fragile pact.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: Grain being loaded at a port in Izmail, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Syria’s Assad Expected to Attend Arab League Summit
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad is expected to participate in the meeting for the first time since brutally crushing his country’s Arab Spring uprising.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, left, with Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan of the United Arab Emirates in March in Abu Dhabi. The Syrian leader had been shunned by many Arab nations for more than a decade.

item.title: For Biden, Debt Limit Crisis Complicates Trip to Asia
item.description: Volatility has become the new norm in Washington as the president heads to Japan, where he will reassure world leaders that the debt ceiling showdown will not upend the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Biden administration warned that a default would only embolden America’s adversaries.

item.title: Chinese Comedy Firm Fined $2 Million For Joke ‘Insulting’ Military
item.description: The penalty came after a popular comedian joked about a military slogan often used by China’s leader, Xi Jinping, who has strictly curbed expression.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Olivia Wang
item.media:description: Xiaoguo Culture Media’s theater in Shanghai on Wednesday.

item.title: The Plan to Build a New Capital
item.description: Jakarta is sinking, and Indonesia’s president has chosen to move the capital. The Times accompanied him on a tour.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Gains Near Bakhmut Raise Ukraine’s Hopes of a Turning Tide
item.description: The advances have been small, and Russians still hold most of the city, but Ukrainians say they see a meaningful shift in momentum.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: The 28th Mechanized Brigade of the Ukrainian Army in a BMP armored vehicle during an operation to fire on a Russian target in the direction of Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine, in May.

item.title: The Religious Right’s Hidden Sway as Japan Trails Allies on Gay Rights
item.description: As a G7 summit nears in Hiroshima, Japan is under pressure to show greater support for equality. A national Shinto group has spread a more hostile message.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers at Aiiro Cafe, a bar in Shinjuku Nichome, Tokyo’s largest gay neighborhood. Japan is the only nation in the Group of 7 that has not legalized same-sex unions.

item.title: Taiwan’s Opposition Picks Hou Yu-ih, a Moderate, for Presidential Race
item.description: The Kuomintang nominated Hou Yu-ih, a popular mayor who has said little about geopolitical issues, as the party tries to appeal to voters wary of Beijing.
item.dc:creator: John Liu and Paul Mozur
item.media:description: Hou Yu-ih, the mayor of New Taipei City, has tried to strike a middle ground within the Kuomintang on Taiwan’s relations with China.

item.title: Russian-Controlled Dam Risks Flooding in Southern Ukraine
item.description: The development is a dramatic turnabout after the reservoir had reached a historic low. The dam, which lies along the front line, has been a point of tension throughout the war.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen and Haley Willis

item.title: Johannesburg, Where Mayors Last Just Months, or Even Only Weeks
item.description: South Africa’s largest city is now on its sixth different mayor in 22 months. While politicians argue over power, residents struggle with dry taps, heaps of garbage and dilapidated buildings.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: In Johannesburg this month. The city has had six mayors in the past 22 months.

item.title: Biden Abruptly Cuts Short an Asia-Pacific Visit, to China’s Benefit
item.description: A Pacific island nation had gone to great lengths to host the U.S. president. Now a region is left to wonder again about American steadfastness.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden meeting with congressional leadership to discuss the debt limit, at the White House in Washington, on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Shot Down Hypersonic Russian Missiles Over Kyiv
item.description: A Russian barrage also damaged a U.S.-made Patriot air-defense system, but officials said it was still working.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: American-made Patriot missile launchers in Warsaw, Poland. Two Patriot systems are believed to be in Ukraine.

item.title: Chief of Ukraine Supreme Court Is Arrested and Accused of Bribery
item.description: ‘This is a dark day in the history of the court,’ its judges said.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Semen Kryvonos, left, and Oleksandr Klymenko, directors of separate anti-corruption bodies in Ukraine, on Tuesday in Kyiv announcing the detention of the head of the country’s Supreme Court.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine Says It Shot Down Hypersonic Missiles
item.description: Also, a dim outlook for Cambodia’s opposition.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Police officers investigating fragments of a Russian rocket that fell down in a city zoo after it was shot down by air defense system during the night Russian rocket attack in Kyiv early Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Vetoes Legislation That Would Reinstate Tariffs on Some Solar Panels
item.description: President Biden announced a two-year pause on the tariffs last year after importers complained that the penalties would threaten broader adoption of solar energy in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Workers producing modules for solar panels at a factory in Suqian, China.

item.title: Guatemala’s elPeriodico Closes After Government Jails Publisher
item.description: On Monday, elPeriodico, an investigative daily in Guatemala, published its final edition after more than 26 years. Its executive editor is in jail and some of its reporters are in exile.
item.dc:creator: Jody García and Elda Cantú
item.media:credit: Simone Dalmasso for The New York Times
item.media:description: The presses are now silent at the elPeriodico newspaper offices in Guatemala City.

item.title: War in Sudan Unleashes New Wave of Violence in Darfur
item.description: The war in Sudan has unleashed a new wave of violence in the western region of Darfur, sending tens of thousands into neighboring Chad, where a new humanitarian crisis is looming.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Yagazie Emezi
item.media:credit: Yagazie Emezi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Partial view of Koufroun where hundreds of mainly Sudanese women and children camp out in makeshift tents, awaiting aid.

item.title: Bird Flu Vaccine Authorized for Emergency Use in California Condors
item.description: More than 20 of the birds, which are critically endangered, have died in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
item.media:description: A California condor at the Los Angeles Zoo.

item.title: Ukraine’s First Lady Visits Seoul, Requesting Nonlethal Military Aid
item.description: While Olena Zelenska asked for military equipment to fight the war, South Korea pledged more nonmilitary aid to help Ukraine rebuild.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: In a photo from the South Korean Presidential Office, President Yoon Suk Yeol meets with Ukraine’s first lady, Olena Zelenska, in Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Team to Counter Tech Espionage Unveils Cases Involving China and Russia
item.description: A new division set up by the government to pursue sanctions evasion and technology espionage announced arrests of individuals with ties to foreign governments.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Matthew G. Olsen, the assistant attorney general of the Justice Department’s national security division, said that the cases showed the U.S. ability “to accelerate investigations and surge our collective resources to defend against these threats.”

item.title: Putin Faces Military Setbacks and Disunity
item.description: The problems that have hindered Russia’s 15-month war are still festering: stretched resources and disunity in the ranks. Still, Mr. Putin’s resolve augurs a willingness to prosecute a long war.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin delivering a speech during the Victory Day parade in Moscow last week. The photo was released by state-controlled media.

item.title: African Leaders Plan ‘Peace Mission’ to Russia and Ukraine
item.description: South Africa’s president said officials from six nations would visit Kyiv and Moscow as part of the initiative. The time frame remained unclear.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, as well as leaders from Egypt, Zambia, Senegal, Uganda and the Republic of Congo, will visit Moscow and Kyiv in an attempt to end the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Global Executions Highest in 5 Years, Amnesty International Says
item.description: Egypt, Iran and Saudi Arabia carried out 90 percent of the executions recorded last year, the rights group said. The numbers did not include estimates of “thousands” in China, it said, citing a lack of transparency.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A protest against executions and detentions in Iran in New York in December. Executions in Iran increased by 83 percent to 576 in 2022, according to the Amnesty report.

item.title: On an Austrian Train, Hitler’s Voice Played Over the Loudspeakers
item.description: Two men have been questioned in the bizarre case, where Hitler could be heard over an express train’s P.A. system. The episode has led to outrage and head-scratching.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A commuter train in Vienna in January.

item.title: Oxford University Removes Sackler Name From Buildings
item.description: The elite British university has become the latest in a long series of institutions to publicly distance themselves from the family because of some of its members’ ties to the opioid crisis.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Bridge of Sighs and Hertford College, part of Oxford University, in 2022.

item.title: Turkey’s Opposition Struggles to Chart Path as Runoff Nears
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan looks likely to benefit most from the votes that went to an ultranationalist candidate eliminated in the first round.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Safak Timur and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: A poster in Ankara, the Turkish capital, on Monday showing the opposition candidate, Kemal Kilicdaroglu.

item.title: Ukraine’s Push Around Bakhmut Presents Russia with Tough Decisions
item.description: Kyiv’s forces have reclaimed ground near the city that it took Russian forces months to seize, raising pressure on Moscow to devote more fighters and equipment there.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A soldier of the 28th Mechanized Brigade of the Ukrainian Army firing at a Russian target near Bakhmut, in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, this month.

item.title: South Korea Wants More Babies, Just Not in These Places
item.description: Hundreds of restaurants, museums, cafes and other public establishments in the country ban children from entering. One lawmaker is pushing to get rid of the policy.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: A no-kids-allowed sign on the door of a cafe in Seoul. Supporters of the child-free zone policy say it helps prevent accidents and property damage as well as injuries to young children.

item.title: Cambodia Disqualifies Main Opposition Party Ahead of Election
item.description: Prime Minister Hun Sen, whose grip on power has lasted 38 years, has said he wants his son to succeed him, laying the groundwork for a new political dynasty.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:description: Candlelight Party supporters during an election campaign in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, in 2022.

item.title: European leaders gather in Iceland to discuss human rights and support for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine virtually addressed the Council of Europe summit in Reykjavik, Iceland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Pledges for more military aid from Ukraine’s European allies.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, right, and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met at the British leader’s country residence outside London on Monday.

item.title: In European Tour, Zelensky Reaps Billions More in Promised Military Aid
item.description: His trips to Britain, Germany, France and Italy demonstrated the shifting political landscape when it comes to supporting Kyiv, as concerns grow about U.S. backing as the presidential election looms.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, right, and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met at the British leader’s country residence outside London on Monday.

item.title: Fire at Hostel in Wellington, New Zealand, Kills at Least 6
item.description: Eleven people were still unaccounted for, an official said. The cause of the fire was not yet known.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Graham-McLay
item.media:credit: Ben Mckay/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Firefighters at the site of a fatal fire at a hostel in Wellington, New Zealand, on Tuesday morning.

item.title: Former U.S. Embassy Employee Is Being Held in Moscow, Russian State News Says
item.description: The State Department had no immediate comment on the report that the man, identified as Robert Shonov, had been arrested and charged with conspiracy.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: An entrance to the Lefortovo Prison in Moscow. Tass, the Russian state news agency, said a former U.S. Embassy employee identified as Robert Shonov was being held there.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Runoff in Turkey
item.description: Also, Thailand’s opposition parties agreed to form a coalition.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: People walking by banners featuring President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Istanbul on Monday.

item.title: Mexico’s Lavish Presidential Plane Arrives at Its New Home in Tajikistan
item.description: Andrés Manuel López Obrador, the president of Mexico, who had called the jet an example of excess, had spent years trying to find a suitor for it.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: The Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner, Mexico’s presidential jet, which was sold to Tajikistan for $92 million, takes off from Benito Juarez International Airport, in Mexico City.

item.title: With New Weapons, Ukraine Has Much of What It Needs for Counteroffensive, Analysts Say
item.description: The additions to Ukraine’s arsenal, which include more tanks, drones and other weapons from Germany, may signal that Western officials believe Kyiv’s forces could reclaim significant swaths of territory.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: German and Danish military personnel trained Ukrainians crews on how to operate and maintain Leopard tanks, in Kleitz, Germany, this month.

item.title: World Health Organization Warns Against Using Artificial Sweeteners
item.description: Continued consumption doesn’t reduce weight and could increase the risk of Type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular diseases and mortality in adults, the W.H.O. said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin
item.media:description: Some alternatives to sugar, when consumed long term, do not serve to reduce body fat in either adults or children, the W.H.O. said in a statement on Monday.

item.title: In First, Palestinian Displacement Commemorated at United Nations
item.description: The event, marking the displacement of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians when Israel was created, was condemned by the Israeli ambassador to the world body.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, spoke at the event for the 75th anniversary of the Nakba at the United Nations headquarters on Monday.

item.title: Erdogan’s Grip on Power Is Loosened but Not Broken, Vote Shows
item.description: Despite a struggling economy, the disastrous earthquakes in February and Turkey’s drift toward one-man rule, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan was in the lead ahead of a runoff.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Huge posters featuring President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey hang from buildings in Istanbul on Monday.

item.title: Belarus State Media Release a Photo of Lukashenko Amid Ill Health Rumors
item.description: Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, a Kremlin ally, had not been shown since he attended events last week celebrating the Soviet Union’s triumph over Nazi Germany in 1945.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: President Alexander G. Lukashenko at the Victory Day military parade in Moscow last week, in a photo from Russian state media.
